newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-South Australia water deal to NW Water group.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-South Australia water deal to NW Water group.

text.p: The South Australian government said on Thursday it had signed a A$110 million contract with international consortium Riverland Water for ten new water filtration plants to be built in the state.

Riverland Water is a consortium comprising North West Water Australia, a subsidiary of Britain's North West Water Plc, AMP Investments, and U.S. engineering group Bechtel Enterprises, it said in a statement.
State Infrastructure Minister John Olsen said under the 25 year contract, Riverland Water would finance, design, build and operate the ten water treatment plants.
The consortium had committed to providing more than A$200 million in export sales in the first ten years, he said.
Including ancillary works by the State-owned SA Water, the value of construction to be carried out over the next three years to bring the project to completion would be about A$110 million, he said.

Olsen said the government had also finalised a A$7 million project for Australia's first private wastewater treatment plant, to be financed, built owned and operated by Henry Walker Environmental, a subsidiary of Henry Walker Group Ltd.
Construction of the plant would commence in October 1996, with completion expected by mid 1997, he said.
